content: In RingTheory.RootsOfUnity.Basic I am amused to note that after the initial rootsOfUnity section (initial lemmas, valid for CommMonoids) there is a CommSemiring section (lines 134 to 179) and the lemmas there also all work fine for CommMonoids :-) What is the reason that they are proved for CommSemirings? Could there be a justification for this? For example 99% of the time they're applied to RingHoms and people don't want to write .toMulHom?
Is there a reason they're not proved for MonoidHomClass?
I am pretty sure this is just some sort of historical accident. Feel free to PR any generalization :)
Kevin, we shouldn't be writing .toMulHom, we have coercions for that sort of thing.
